member.name: T:Telogis.GeoBase.CountryToString
member.summary: This class contains a single static method. The method returns a well-formatted string to represent any .

remarks.para: It is possible to use the ToString() method of the Country enum, but for display purposes it is preferential to use this method to ensure that the country's name is displayed correctly.
For example the "Bosnia and Herzegovina" has an enum ToString of "BosniaAndHerzegovina", which is undesirable.
In all cases this method will return the country correctly, ie "Bosnia and Herzegovina".

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.CountryToString.ToString(Telogis.GeoBase.Country)
member.summary: Gets a well-formatted name for any given
member.param: The Country to get name for
member.returns: A string containing the Country name eg "Trinidad and Tobago"
member.remarks: It is mostly possible to use the ToString() method of the Country enum, but for display purposes this is not suitable, as some countries like "Bosnia and Herzegovina" have an enum ToString of "BosniaAndHerzegovina". In all cases this method will return the country correctly, ie "Bosnia and Herzegovina".

member.name: T:Telogis.GeoBase.CountryToIso3166
member.summary: This class contains a single static method. The method returns the ISO 3166-1-alpha-2 code for any .

example.code: String cname = CountryToIso3166.ToString(Country.UK); // cname = "GBR"

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.CountryToIso3166.ToString(Telogis.GeoBase.Country)
member.summary: Gets the ISO 3166-1-alpha-2 code any given
member.param: The Country to get the ISO 3166-1-alpha-2 code for
member.returns: A string containing the Country's ISO 3166-1-alpha-2 code eg "US"

member.name: T:Telogis.GeoBase.Iso3166ToCountry
member.summary: This class contains a single static method. The method returns the for any ISO 3166-1-alpha-2 code.

example.code: Country country = Iso3166ToCountry.ToCountry(string iso3166Country); // country = "Country.UK"

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Iso3166ToCountry.ToCountry(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the for any given ISO 3166-1-alpha-2 code.
member.param: The ISO 3166-1-alpha-2 code to get the Country for.
member.returns: A from the ISO 3166-1-alpha-2 code eg Country.UK

member.name: T:Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.RemoteClusterLayer
member.summary: RemoteClusterLayer is responsible for the fetching, caching, indexing of clusters fetched from a ClusterPage running under an ASP.NET server. All clustering information (clusters / images etc) is fetched asynchronously. OnClustersChanged is called when updated clusters or images are available. Clusters will be fetched using the BoundingBox and worldpx of the most recent call to QueryClusters.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.RemoteClusterLayer.#ctor(System.Uri)
member.summary: RemoteClusterLayer is responsible for the fetching, caching, and indexing of clusters and associated features. Feature infomation is fetched asynchronously from the specified url. It is assumed that the url points to an ASPX page being served using ClusterPage.ServeRequest. is called when new features are available.
member.param: The URI of the page on the ASP.NET server that will supply cluster information and visualizations.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.RemoteClusterLayer.Dispose
member.summary: Disposes of this cluster layer.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.RemoteClusterLayer.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Disposes of this cluster layer.
member.param: Whether Dispose() has been called explicitly.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.RemoteClusterLayer.BeginGetClusters(System.Int32,Telogis.GeoBase.BoundingBox,System.AsyncCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Starts calculating clusters asynchronously.
member.param: The width, in pixels, of the entire area where clusterable features can be situated.
The bounding box for the visible portion of the map for which clusters are calculated.
A callback that is executed when the cluster calculation is complete.
The state of the asynchronous cluster calculation
member.returns: An IAsyncResult allowing the caller to query the state of the calculation.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.RemoteClusterLayer.EndGetClusters(System.IAsyncResult)
member.summary: Returns the clusters calculated asynchronously by when the calculation is complete.
member.param: The IAsyncResult that was returned by BeginGetClusters.
member.returns: The set of clusters that was calculated by the cluster layer.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.RemoteClusterLayer.BeginGetImage(System.String,System.AsyncCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Obtains the image for a cluster synchronously.
member.param: The name (image ID) of the cluster image to obtain from the visualizer () of the cluster layer.
A callback that is executed when the image for the cluster is ready.
The state of the operation.
member.returns: An IAsyncResult allowing the caller to query the state of the operation.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.RemoteClusterLayer.EndGetImage(System.IAsyncResult)
member.summary: Returns the image for a cluster made available by a call to .
member.param: The IAsyncResult that was returned by BeginGetImage.
member.returns: The image of the cluster.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.RemoteClusterLayer.BeginRefresh(System.AsyncCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Begin an unscheduled refresh of feature data asynchronously.
member.param: A callback that is executed when the cluster has refreshed.
A user-defined object that holds state information about the asynchronous operation.
member.returns: An IAsyncResult that allows the caller to query the state of the refresh operation.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.RemoteClusterLayer.EndRefresh(System.IAsyncResult)
member.summary: Finish up after an asynchronous refresh begun by a call to BeginRefresh.
member.param: The IAsyncResult value returned by BeginRefresh.

member.summary: ClusterVisualizationDot displays Clusters as colored circle containing the number of elements in the Cluster. The color of the circle depends on how many elements the Cluster contains.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.ClusterVisualizationDot.GetImage(System.String)

member.returns: The visualization represented by the ImageId

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.ClusterVisualizationDot.Visualize(System.Drawing.Size,System.Drawing.Point,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates the image for a cluster with a given size, center and number of items.
member.param: The size of the rectangle representing the area covered by the cluster.
The center of the cluster relative to the cluster rectangle. This might not be the center of the rectangle, as the center depends on the location of the items within the cluster.
The count of items within the cluster.
member.returns: An image representing the cluster.

member.name: T:Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.ClusterRenderer
member.summary:
The ClusterRenderer class renders clusters from an on a map.
A ClusterRenderer will automatically Invalidate the most recent MapCtrl drawn to when the underlying clusters change. If clusters are desired on more than one MapCtrl it is recommended to use a separate ClusterRenderer for each.

member.summary: The cluster layer to be rendered.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.ClusterRenderer.#ctor(Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.IClusterLayer)
member.summary:
Creates and initializes the cluster renderer.
A ClusterRenderer will automatically Invalidate the most recent MapCtrl drawn to when the underlying clusters change. If clusters are desired on more than one MapCtrl it is recommended to use a separate ClusterRenderer for each.
member.param: The cluster layer that produces and visualizes the clusters.

member.name: T:Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.TransientClusterLayer
member.summary: TransientClusterLayer is responsible for the fetching and indexing clusters and associated features. Feature infomation is fetched every time it calculates clusters.
member.remarks: LocalClusterLayer is intended to act as a temporary object that persists only as long as it takes to generate a set of clusters. If the feature data that is grouped into clusters does not change frequently, you might consider using Instead. LocalClusterLayer caches point data to improve performance.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.TransientClusterLayer.#ctor(Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.IClusteringAlgorithm,Telogis.GeoBase.DataSources.IPointFeatureSource,Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.ClusterSummaryDelegate,Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.IClusterVisualization)
member.summary: Creates and initializes a transient cluster layer for fetching and indexing clusters.
member.param: The clustering algorithm to use for combining map features into clusters.
A data source for obtaining point features to be clustered.
A function for combining the features in a cluster into a single summary object.
A visualizer for producing the image that appears on maps to represent the cluster.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.TransientClusterLayer.BeginRefresh(System.AsyncCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Starts updating the feature data for the clusters asynchronously.
member.param: A callback that is executed when the feature data is updated.
A user-defined object that represents the state of the asynchronous update.
member.returns: An IAsyncResult allowing the caller to query the state of the calculation.
member.remarks: TransientClusterLayer automatically updates its feature data every time you call . Calling this method allows you to force a refresh and execute the callback without generating new clusters.

member.name: T:Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.ColumnClustering
member.summary: A clustering algorithm which works by first creating a grid of clusters This clustering algorithm attempts to merge clusters so that cluster labels will not be incorrectly placed. This should mean that the center of any cluster icon will be over the centroid of the cluster.
member.remarks: First partitions the features into a grid of small sub clusters Where possible these sub clusters are combined into a grid of clusters. Edge sub clusters are not initially placed on the grid - instead they are merged into adjacent clusters in a second pass. This is so that the cluster labels do not have to be drawn a large distance from the centroid of the cluster.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.ColumnClustering.CalculateClusters(Telogis.GeoBase.IMap,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Telogis.GeoBase.DataSources.IPointFeature},Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.ClusterSummaryDelegate,Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.IClusterVisualization)
member.summary: Calculates the clusters for a specified map and set of features.
member.param: The map to contain the clusters.
The features on the map to be grouped into clusters.
A function for summarizing the features in a cluster. The results of this summary are assigned to the property of each cluster.
An object to visualize clusters into images.
member.returns: A collection of cluster objects.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.ColumnClustering.GroupEdgeFeatures(System.Collections.Generic.List{Telogis.GeoBase.Clustering.FeatureGroup})
member.summary:
Attempts to group unclustered FeatureGroups using various methods
First it tries to expand into another feature group or empty space in the directions that the feature group icon is cut off Next it tries to expand into an intermediate cluster in the directions that the feature group icon is cut off Next it attempts to expand into an intermediate cluster in any direction Next it attempts to expand in any direction into any nearby feature group or empty space Finally it converts any feature groups with icons which aren't cut off directly into clusters. If any feature groups fail to expand when they need to, they are simply converted into intermediate clusters.

member.name: F:Telogis.GeoBase.Traffic.InrixPredictiveRealTimeTrafficSource.fractionForClass
member.summary: The next hour's prediction is given in "3,3,3,3" format, each number is a color (class id) in order to return next hour's speed, we need to convert the color (which means 3 here) to a speed. Because 3 is in the range of 92% -- 100% of the reference speed category, so 0.96 = (0.92 + 1.0)/2 = 0.96. The same function is used for calculating class one, two, three...

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Routing.IRoute.GetRouteHighlight
member.summary: Get the likely route that was taken between the points in a given route history, without generating natural language directions or checking for route legality.
member.returns: without natural language directions.

remarks.para: Route Highlighting is used to display the most likely route taken based on a series of RouteStops. This is useful when only the route stops are known, and the actual route taken is not known. In the example below, figure 1 shows three route stops (the arrows depict the vehicle's heading) without a known route. When the "Highlight" button is pressed, GetRouteHighlight() is called, the most likely directions are calculated, and the Route Highlight is displayed on the map, as shown in figure 2.
The route is calculated based on the RouteStops' properties:
If not all of these RouteStop properties are known, the bare minimum that can be used is: Lat, Lon, TimeSincePreviousStop

example.para: This example is designed with just a MapCtrl, and a button. When the program is loaded, the RouteStops are displayed with their headings. When the button is pressed, the route highlight is rendered on the map. The map's properties are as follows:
Figure 1
Figure 2

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Routing.Route.AddStop(Telogis.GeoBase.RouteStop)
member.summary: Adds a at the most logical place in the list. Multiple stops at the same location are ignored.
member.remarks:
If a high-numbered is added between two lower numbered ones, this method will re-order those stops to avoid back-tracking. For example, imagine a straight road with stops 1 and 2 on it. Using this method, should stop 3 be added between 1 and 2, the stops will be re-ordered to run 1,2,3.
Please note that this is not comparable to the optimization available via .
Related articles: Using a RouteMatrix.
member.param: The to add.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Routing.Route.ForceRecalculate
member.summary: Force the route to be recalculated. This should be called if anything the route is unaware of changes.

remarks.para: This method should be called if a Route has already calculated directions using GetDirections, and then subsequently had changes made to its or .
Examples include setting a in the 's list, or changing the height of your .

If not called under these circumstances then the route will simply return previously calculated directions. These may violate a GeoFence or produce a route unsuitable for the given vehicle specifications.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Routing.Route.GetRouteHighlight
member.summary: Get the likely route that was taken between the points in a given route history, without generating natural language directions or checking for route legality.
member.returns: without natural language directions.

remarks.para: Route Highlighting is used to display the most likely route taken based on a series of RouteStops. This is useful when only the route stops are known, and the actual route taken is not known. In the example below, figure 1 shows three route stops (the arrows depict the vehicle's heading) without a known route. When the "Highlight" button is pressed, GetRouteHighlight() is called, the most likely directions are calculated, and the Route Highlight is displayed on the map, as shown in figure 2.
The route is calculated based on the RouteStops' properties:
If not all of these RouteStop properties are known, the bare minimum that can be used is: Lat, Lon, TimeSincePreviousStop

example.para: This example is designed with just a MapCtrl, and a button. When the program is loaded, the RouteStops are displayed with their headings. When the button is pressed, the route highlight is rendered on the map. The map's properties are as follows:
Figure 1
Figure 2

Column headings that GeoBase does not recognize, will be ignored.

member.summary: Gets the speed limit on a link for a vehicle whose specifications are in the VehicleSpec of this Route.
member.remarks: A speed limit is defined as a single-link constraint that applies to the specified link and that is valid for this Route's VehicleSpec. summary.para: Describes the type of the GPS fix: None, 2D or 3D.

A 2D fix (FixType2d) is sufficient to provide location information. A 3D fix (FixType3d) is typically required for routing operations and directions generation. This is because routing operations and directions generation require a level of precision that only a 3D fix can provide.

member.summary: The Position structure describes various attributes of a GPS unit (such as location, signal quality, speed and heading) as recorded from a GPS unit at an instant in time.

Used primarily by GPS and classes.

member.name: F:Telogis.GeoBase.Navigation.Position.heading
member.summary: The recorded heading, measured in degrees. See remarks.
member.remarks: The heading describes the direction of travel as an angle (measure clockwise) from due North. For example, a heading of zero degrees represents due North, and a heading of 90 degrees represents due East. Due to the nature of GPS, this may become unreliable at low speeds. Consider using the FilteredGps class.

member.name: P:Telogis.GeoBase.Navigation.InteractiveGps.SpeedMultiplier
member.summary:
The amount by which the speed of the interactive GPS changes when the SHIFT key is down.
The value of Speed is periodically multiplied by this value to simulate acceleration when the SHIFT key is pressed. Pressing the MINUS key reduces this value (to a minimum value of 1) and pressing the PLUS key increases this value (to a maximum of 7).

member.name: P:Telogis.GeoBase.Navigation.InteractiveGps.Speed
member.summary: The simulated speed of the interactive GPS.
member.remarks: This value can be increased by pressing the SHIFT key when the value of SpeedMultiplier is greater than one and decreased by pressing the CTRL key.

member.name: T:Telogis.GeoBase.Navigation.CEGps
member.summary: A GPS implementation for use with Windows CE 5.01 and above.

remarks.para: This class is designed for Windows CE/Windows Mobile devices which support the Microsoft GPS Intermediate Driver (GPSID). This allows multiple applications on your device to access GPS data simultaneously.
If your mobile device/GPS does not support GPSID, the class can be used to interface with standard NMEA devices via a COM port.
Related articles: The IGps Interface.

summary.i: For internal use. Marks a bad data packet.

member.returns: Device state information

member.summary: Initialize the GPS.

remarks.para: This is a convenience method, designed to be run on a Windows Mobile device, which will first try to set up a class. If this is not possible, it will then scan the COM ports to create an class. As a last resort it will create a class.
Related articles: The IGps Interface.

returns.para: Returns a centered on (0,0) if no hardware is found.
Returns a if the hardware is detected as conforming to the NMEA standard.

member.name: T:Telogis.GeoBase.Navigation.NMEAGps
member.summary: Represents a GPS unit conforming to the NMEA standard. See remarks.

remarks.para: The NMEAGps class listens for the following standard NMEA GPS sentences:
GGA - 3D location and precision information
GSA - active satellites
RMC - position, velocity and time

The class connects to a COM port, and is intended for interfacing directly with NMEA standard GPS hardware. This requires exclusive access to the COM port, and may not be compatible with other applications on the same device which require GPS data.

If your device supports the Microsoft GPS Intermediate Driver (GPSID), we recommend either using the class, or using with a GPSID-managed Virtual COM port. Both of these approaches will allow multiple applications to access GPS information simultaneously.
See the GPSID documentation for more details: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb202128.aspx.
Related articles: The IGps Interface.

member.name: F:Telogis.GeoBase.Navigation.NMEAGps.SpeedThreshold
member.summary: Speed threshold of this GPS unit.

remarks.para:
SpeedThreshold is measured in knots. You may use
to convert between units.

To avoid GPS drift the GPS unit's heading information (read directly from the GPS unit's GPSRMC tag by the NMEAGps object) will be ignored unless the speed of the GPS unit exceeds this SpeedThreshold value.

member.summary: A balance between accuracy and processor intensiveness.

member.name: F:Telogis.GeoBase.MapQuality.Perfect
member.summary: This mode results in the most accurate maps, but is also the most processor intensive.

member.name: F:Telogis.GeoBase.MapQuality.FastStreets
member.summary: This mode is like Perfect except that lines are drawn using Xiaolin Wu's anti-aliasing algorithm to speed rendering.

member.name: T:Telogis.GeoBase.Map
member.summary: Generates Maps.

remarks.para: Map classes can also be used to translate from X, Y points to for panning and zooming operations.

A Map object is not a lightweight object. Operations on the map are swift but the object has a memory footprint proportional to the size of the image to be generated. As such, it is recommended that the pattern below be used when dealing with maps in a transient fashion.
Also note that the Image returned by GetMap will be disposed when the Map object is disposed. To work around this copy the Bitmap object as in the following snippet.
Related articles: Map Concept.

member.name: P:Telogis.GeoBase.Map.Progressive
member.summary: Whether the map should be drawn in progressive mode, a mode designed for a MapCtrl that is being used in a navigation context - where the bounding box of the map does not change a lot from one rendering to the next.
member.remarks: In non-progressive mode, each time the map is rendered the polygons, lines, points and streets are queried afresh from the data file. In progressive mode, polygons and streets are only queried from the data file on every alternate rendering. On renderings when they are not queried, the only features that are drawn are those that were drawn the previous time the map was rendered. This causes a performance improvement.

member.name: P:Telogis.GeoBase.Map.CenterPixelOffset
member.summary: Used to line up tiles. Sets an offset , in pixels, for the center of this Map tile, relative to the point of the center Map tile.

remarks.para: CenterPixelOffset allows you to treat the Map object conceptually as an infinitely large map. The map is centered around the point. returns a portion of the infinite map, Width wide and Height high. By setting CenterPixelOffset the portion of the underlying map that is rendered by can be controlled. This allows you to request several smaller maps from the same object and then reconstruct a larger map from these tiles. This is especially useful in web applications.
Not valid on GeoStream maps, which can already be treated this way.

example.para: Consider an underlying object. Overlaid are three maps, each generated by setting the Width and Height to 100 each, then adjusting the for each. The first map (Map 1) has the set to (0,0), so it renders a map exactly as normal, centered around the underlying map's .
The second map (Map 2) has the same as Map 1 but has set to (-100,0) it renders an area to the left of Map 1.
Similarly, Map 3 is positioned below and to the left Map 1 as it has the same but a of (-100,100) - a sideways shift of 100 pixels and 100 pixels lower.

member.name: P:Telogis.GeoBase.Map.ProjectionCentre
member.summary: Represents the center of the map projection. By default this value is null and the center is always the center of the visible map area.
member.remarks:
Not settable on GeoStream maps, which are never projected.
By setting ProjectionCentre one is able to lock the center of the map projection. Rather than updating the projection to center on the center of the displayed map, the center will remain fixed as the map is panned around. As the map is panned further away from the center the display will appear more skewed, however the constant center allows sections of map to be stitched together. This is only possible when the center is locked, as otherwise the automatically reprojected map segments will not match up.

member.name: P:Telogis.GeoBase.Map.Zooms
member.summary: Defines the set of zoom levels to use.
member.remarks: A zoom level represents the number of Supertiles required to cover the world (horizontally). Zoom levels should always be ordered from lowest (least zoomed) to highest. Only the specified zoom levels will be used when rendering the map.

member.name: P:Telogis.GeoBase.Map.ZoomLevel
member.summary: This defines the current zoom level. This differs from Zoom, in that ZoomLevel is expressed in terms of the array of Zooms; ZoomLevel is an index into the array.
member.remarks: This property corresponds to the index into the Zooms array that is currently set. This property is generally preferable to using Zoom, as it sets the exact zoom level, while using Zoom will cause the map to zoom to the closest available ZoomLevel that is as big or larger than the requested Zoom.

member.name: T:Telogis.GeoBase.RenderMode
member.summary: An enumeration representing the three stages of rendering, which are used by and to control the priority and behavior of rendering objects.

remarks.para: RenderMode values may be used to give priority to the rendering of certain objects, entirely independent of their order in a .

When rendering occurs four passes are made over the objects in a . During the first pass, objects that implement PreStreets rendering are drawn. The second pass covers PreLabelling, the third Labelling and the fourth PostLabelling. There is essentially no difference in the behavior of objects rendered in PreLabelling or Labelling, other than that PreLabelling objects render first. This is nevertheless an important distinction as it allows for two levels of priority in rendering before labels are drawn on the map. An example is which renders the icon in PreLabelling, and then follows up by rendering the informational balloon in Labelling. This split-level rendering ensures that all PushPin icons are d on the map before balloons are drawn, thus allowing the use of to ensure that no balloon obscures a .
Related articles: How Renderers Work.

member.name: F:Telogis.GeoBase.RenderMode.None
member.summary: Objects with a RenderMode of None are not rendered.

member.name: F:Telogis.GeoBase.RenderMode.PreStreets
member.summary: Objects that render PreStreets are drawn before the streets are rendered - typically used for satellite imagery.

member.name: F:Telogis.GeoBase.RenderMode.PreLabelling
member.summary: Objects that render in PreLabelling are drawn first, before labels are rendered.

member.name: F:Telogis.GeoBase.RenderMode.Labelling
member.summary: Objects that render in Labelling are drawn after those that render in PreLabelling, but before labels are rendered.

member.name: F:Telogis.GeoBase.RenderMode.PostLabelling
member.summary: Objects that render PostLabelling are drawn last, after labels are rendered.

member.name: T:Telogis.GeoBase.RenderMask
member.summary: Specifies the layer mask upon which a label should be drawn.
member.remarks:
During rendering, label placement is affected by the position of other labels on the same mask; labels drawn on the Overlay mask are affected only by other labels on the Overlay mask.
GeoBase draws internal labels on the Primary mask by default, but the map style used can change this behavior.

member.name: F:Telogis.GeoBase.RenderMask.None
member.summary: None

member.name: F:Telogis.GeoBase.RenderMask.Primary
member.summary: The primary label rendering mask

member.name: F:Telogis.GeoBase.RenderMask.Overlay
member.summary: The overlay label rendering mask

member.name: F:Telogis.GeoBase.RenderMask.Both
member.summary: Both label rendering masks

remarks.para: This method should reserve an area of the screen to which an object will be rendered. After placement, any future calls to which specify an area that overlaps with this one will return false.
The x, y, width and height parameters describe a rectangle, with the given height and width, with the top-left corner anchored at the co-ordinates specified by x and y.

member.param: The horizontal position of the top left corner of the rectangle.
The vertical position of the top left corner of the rectangle.
The width of the rectangle in pixels
The height of the rectangle in pixels
The buffer value specifies the number of pixels on each side of the object that must remain clear, for the purpose of visual separation.
Specifies a clockwise rotation (in degrees) of the testable area.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.LocalRenderContext.Test(System.Drawing.Rectangle,System.Int32,System.Double,Telogis.GeoBase.RenderMask)
member.summary: Checks whether the given lies over an area reserved by an already placed object.

remarks.para: See for an explanation of buffer values.

This method only checks for overlaps with non-label objects. Support for testing map labels for overlaps is not provided because the sheer number of labels on a typical map would cause the Test to fail in most cases.
By using this method in conjunction with one can control the positioning of renderable components.

member.param: The area to be tested.
The buffer value specifies the number of pixels on each side of the object that must remain clear of other objects, for the purpose of visual separation.
Specifies a clockwise rotation (in degrees) of the testable area.
Specifies which layer to test.
member.returns: True if the tested area is available for placement, false if there is an overlap with an already-placed area.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.LocalRenderContext.Place(System.Drawing.Rectangle,System.Int32,System.Double,Telogis.GeoBase.RenderMask)
member.summary: Reserves the specified screen area for object placement.

remarks.para: The purpose of this method is to reserve an area of the screen to which an object will be rendered. After placement, any future calls to which specify an area that overlaps with this one will return false.
By using this method in conjunction with one can control the positioning of renderable components.

The buffer parameter may be used to specify a 'clear' buffer zone around the outside of the rendered area. The purpose of this zone is to prevent other objects from placing themselves immediately adjacent. A good example is in the placing of s, where a buffer value is used to prevent the edges of balloons touching each other.
It should be noted that adjacent buffers automatically collapse to the minimum separation agreeable to both objects. For example, if object A has a buffer value of 10, and adjacent object B has a buffer value of 5, the buffers will collapse so that the two objects are 10 pixels apart, that being the smallest value acceptable to both A and B.

By using this method in conjunction with
one can control the positioning of renderable components.

member.param: The area to be reserved.
The buffer value specifies the number of pixels on each side of the object that must remain clear, for the purpose of visual separation.
Specifies a clockwise rotation (in degrees) of the placed area.
Specifies which layer to place the label on.

member.name: P:Xheo.Licensing.LicenseServerLimit.Alternates
member.summary: Gets a collection of alternate server URLs to use in case a connection to the primary server cannot be established. If the license is read only then a copy of the collection is returned and any changes made are lost.

member.name: P:Xheo.Licensing.LicenseServerLimit.AllowedFailures
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of times the remote validation can fail before the limit is considered violated. Allows for congestion, and other internet problems.

member.name: P:Xheo.Licensing.LicenseServerLimit.IsLeased
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates if the license should be leased.
member.remarks:
Leased licenses can help reduce network traffic and increase reliability by reducing the number of times a remote server is queried for validation. When a leased license is validated by a , the lease is renewed for the amount of time specified in . ///
XHEO|Licensing must have permission to overwrite the original license file for the lease to renew. If it can't write to the file then the lease is not reviewed, but the license validation still succeeds. The lease is only valid on the machine it was originally granted to. If copied to a new machine a new lease is requested from the license server.

member.name: P:Xheo.Licensing.LicenseServerLimit.LeaseLength
member.summary: Gets or sets the length of a the lease in hours.

member.name: P:Xheo.Licensing.LicenseServerLimit.LeaseExpires
member.summary: Gets or sets the date when the current lease expires.

member.name: P:Xheo.Licensing.LicenseServerLimit.LeasedMachine
member.summary: Gets or sets the profile hash of the machine the license was leased to.

member.name: P:Xheo.Licensing.LicenseServerLimit.UseValidateEx
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates if XHEO|Licensing should call the ValidateEx method on the license server. License server must be running version 2.0 or later.

member.name: P:Xheo.Licensing.LicenseServerLimit.AllowInitialFailure
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates if a failure the first time the Type is requested after the process starts should cause a hard failure.
member.remarks: Previous versions of XHEO|Licensing allowed a minimum number of failures to occur before a hard failure. If the process was restarted before the maximum number of failures occurred, a user could effectively run without ever checking back with the license server. By setting AllowInitialFailure to false, the process must acquire a valid response at least the first time it is requested. Further requests are allowed to fail to enable an ongoing application to continue running even if the license server goes down. Note Rather then using a failure tolerance it is better to use to force the license to obtain a long running validate to eliminate most intermittent problems associated with Internet connectivity.

member.name: T:Telogis.GeoBase.GeoStream.Server.GeoStreamRenderer
member.summary: Abstract base class for custom renderers that generate custom tile layers for GeoStream.

remarks.para: Override this class to define a custom GeoStream renderer. You must implement the abstract method to draw the tiles of your custom layer and implement the abstract property to indicate how long the tiles can remain in the GeoStream tile cache.

Your GeoStreamRenderer class should be added to an aspx file which is placed in the renderers folder of the GeoStream server. (The renderers folder must be created at the root directory of your GeoStream tile server.)
Related articles: Geostream renderers, Rendering your own tiles.

member.name: T:Telogis.GeoBase.Internal.JSONFormatter
member.summary: Serializes and deserializes object graphs to and from JavaScript Object Notation.
member.remarks: Due to the weak typing in JSON, this formatter is not entirely symmetric. Some class information is conveyed by adding a "_class" member and value to each object, specifying the .NET assembly and type information for the object. However, in some situations, the deserializer cannot determine what the expected type of a member is. This occurs in the following situations: - The class implements ISerializable, or has an ISerializationSurrogate. In this case, the deserializer will try and determine the type by looking for a field on the object with the same name. - The class contains a weakly typed (object) member or array. - The top level object being deserialized is an array, an enum, or a numeric primitive. When the type cannot be determined due to one of these cases, numeric primitives are always deserialized as doubles, Enums are always deserialized as strings, and arrays are always deserialized as arrays of objects, regardless of their original typing. These caveats mean that you need to take special care in deserialization: If your class implements ISerializable, ensure it fetches any arrays from the SerializationInfo structure as arrays of objects, then uses Array.CopyTo() to copy them into a strongly typed array if neccessary. Attempting to use SerializationInfo.GetValue with the strongly typed array directly will fail. If your objects contain weakly typed members, bear in mind that primitives, arrays, and Enums assigned to these will be deserialized as above.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Internal.JSONFormatter.ParseNumber(System.String)
member.summary: Reliably parse a number without using TryParse (doesn't exist on CE) or using Exceptions (slow).
member.param: A string to parse.
member.returns: The parsed number.

member.summary: Searches for a serialization surrogate for the given Type, or any superclass of that Type. The client's version number must meet the minimum version number required by the surrogate.

member.summary: Recurse through the object graph, serializing objects to the hashtable.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Internal.JSONFormatter.IsArrayLikeTypeForClient(System.Type)
member.summary: Whether the supplied type should be serialized as a JSON array. Considers whether the client can deserialize this type as a JSON array.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Internal.JSONFormatter.IsArrayLikeType(System.Type)
member.summary: Determines whether the supplied type should be serialized to and deserialized from a JSON array, rather than an object encapsulating an array. This is true of all .NET types that implement IList; the test fails for types not from the System namespace because certain Telogis types (e.g. GeoFenceCollection) are IList implementers but need to be deserialized as an object (which specifies an explicit type) rather than an array.
member.param: The type to test.
member.returns: Whether should be serialized as an array.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Internal.JSONFormatter.getFilteredAttributes(System.Reflection.MemberInfo,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Filters invalid attributes.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Internal.JSONFormatter.IsFieldSerialized(System.Reflection.FieldInfo,System.String@)
member.summary:
A field is serializable if all of these conditions are met: EIt must be marked with SerializeAttribute.
EIf it is marked with a [Serialialize(OnlyIf=...)] the OnlyIf must match the current GeoStreamMode.
EIf it is marked with a [Serialialize(StartAtVersion=...)] the ClientVersion must be equal to or greater than the current specified version.
EIf it is marked with a [Serialialize(StopAtVersion=...)] the ClientVersion must be less than the specified version.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Internal.JSONFormatter.IsPropertySerialized(System.Reflection.PropertyInfo,System.String@)
member.summary:
A property is serializable if all of these conditions are met: EIt must be marked with SerializeAttribute.
EIt must have a getter.
EIt must not be indexed
EIf it is marked with a [Serialialize(OnlyIf=...)] the OnlyIf must match the current GeoStreamMode.
EIf it is marked with a [Serialialize(StartAtVersion=...)] the ClientVersion must be equal to or greater than the current specified version.
EIf it is marked with a [Serialialize(StopAtVersion=...)] the ClientVersion must be less than the specified version.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Internal.JSONFormatter.IsFieldDeserialized(System.Reflection.FieldInfo,System.String@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary:
A field is deserializable if all of these conditions are met: EIt must be marked with SerializeAttribute.
EIf it is marked with a [Serialialize(OnlyIf=...)] the OnlyIf must match the current GeoStreamMode.
EIf it is marked with a [Serialialize(StartAtVersion=...)] the ClientVersion must be equal to or greater than the current specified version.
EIf it is marked with a [Serialialize(StopAtVersion=...)] the ClientVersion must be less than the specified version.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Internal.JSONFormatter.IsPropertyDeserialized(System.Reflection.PropertyInfo,System.String@)
member.summary:
A property is deserializable if all of these conditions are met: EIt must be marked with SerializeAttribute.
EIt must have a setter.
EIt must not be indexed
EIf it is marked with a [Serialialize(OnlyIf=...)] the OnlyIf must match the current GeoStreamMode.
EIf it is marked with a [Serialialize(StartAtVersion=...)] the ClientVersion must be equal to or greater than the current specified version.
EIf it is marked with a [Serialialize(StopAtVersion=...)] the ClientVersion must be less than the specified version.

member.name: P:Telogis.GeoBase.Internal.JSONFormatter.ClientVersion
member.summary:
The Assembly version for the client using this JSON Formatter is serializing objects for and deserializing JSON from.
If this is being used in a .NET client, then this matches the Assembly version of this exact assembly. If this is being used in a GeoStream server, then this will be set to the reported assembly version of the client that we are communicating with. Note that regardless of use, this is initially populated with the local assembly version. So upon initialization of an instance of JSONFormatter that is being used to communicate with a remote client, this will possibly return an incorrect Version until this field has been populated. In such cases, this field is populated when a client makes a request.

member.name: T:Telogis.GeoBase.Routing.MultiThreadMatrix
member.summary: Provides functionality similar to , but with the added benefit of being able to specify the number of threads to be used; ideal for multi-core systems working with large matrices. When the matrix is instantiated, the whole matrix is calculated in one go. Using persist provides the option to save the results to disk for faster, subsequent, data retrieval.

remarks.para: When the MultiThreadMatrix is 'persistent' the calculation results are automatically saved and loaded from disk, as and when required.
Related articles: Using a RouteMatrix.

member.name: T:Telogis.GeoBase.Address

summary.para: Represents a physical address retrieved from reverse geocoding. (Reverse geocoding is the process of resolving a location to an ). An may contain such information as street number, street name, city, county and state.
See also for the address type returned from forward geocoding.

remarks.para: Related articles: Geocoding Concept, Searching for a Location, Creating a Simple Web Application, Drill-down Geocoder Tutorial, Creating the Basic Project, Using a Navigator.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Address.ToString
member.summary: Returns a formatted string containing address information, such as may be printed on an envelope.
member.remarks: The string is formatted to return a maximum of "[street number] [street name], [city], [region], [post code], [country]". Any unavailable values are omitted.
member.returns: A string containing address information.

member.name: P:Telogis.GeoBase.Address.Number
member.summary: Number on street, -1 if no number.
member.remarks: In some instances the may not be able to return a street number for the location. In this instance, the Number property will be set to -1.

member.name: P:Telogis.GeoBase.Address.Names
member.summary: Array of street names for the street (some streets may have more than one name).

remarks.para: The street may be identified by a number of different names, such as the I-405 which is also known as the San Diego Freeway. In this instance the most commonly used name will be the first value in the array. Alternate names are not ranked.
Use the array.Length property to check if alternate names exist.

member.name: P:Telogis.GeoBase.Address.PrimaryNameWithNumber
member.summary: The Primary name with the street number if it has one.

member.name: P:Telogis.GeoBase.Address.PrimaryName
member.summary: The primary name for the street.

remarks.para: The street may have multiple names, for example a Highway will have a name of say US-19 but the name that interests us more is its actual street name as rendered on the map.

member.name: P:Telogis.GeoBase.Address.ExtendedNameInfo
member.summary: Array of street name information for the street (some streets may have more than one name).

remarks.para: The street may be identified by a number of different names, such as the I-405 which is also known as the San Diego Freeway. In this instance the most commonly used name will be the first value in the array. Alternate names are not ranked.
Use the array.Length property to check if alternate names exist.

member.summary: The name of the city. This value may be null if relevant city data is unavailable.

member.name: P:Telogis.GeoBase.Address.County
member.summary: The name of the county. This value may be null if relevant Country data is unavailable.

member.name: P:Telogis.GeoBase.Address.SubRegions
member.summary: Suburb and regions where this address is located that subdivide the city.

member.name: P:Telogis.GeoBase.Address.Regions
member.summary: Contains the list of regions for this address, with the most specific region (eg suburb or city) first.

remarks.para: Different countries have different levels of administrative regions.

For example, Germany is divided into 16 Bundeslnder (federal states), which are further divided into Regierungsbezirke (government regions), which in turn are subdivided into Kreise (administrative districts), which may again comprise mter (offices) and Gemeinden (municipalities).

member.name: P:Telogis.GeoBase.Address.Region
member.summary: Name of the largest administrative region (for example: State name in the USA, Bundeslnder name in Germany, or the Province name in Britain). Region may be null if no data is available.

member.name: T:Telogis.GeoBase.MapCtrl
member.summary: Map Control Object for Windows Forms

remarks.para: This object should be used for Windows Forms applications. For ASP.NET and other server applications you should use the Map Object or the class.

There are a number of functions common to most MapCtrl applications. These functions include:
Displaying custom objects on the map.
Responding to mouse clicks.

Custom objects can be displayed on the map by implementing the interface. An example of such an object is the location marker. In order to display multiple objects it is necessary to use a - essentially a collection of renderable objects. The Tutorials section contains a tutorial on s which also covers s.

Rendered objects that need to respond to mouse clicks should implement the interface. The may be used to simplify this procedure. The application example in the Tutorials section contains examples of mouse event handling.

Two keyboard-modifiers affect mouse behavior in MapCtrl by default.
When Shift is depressed, the selected mouse function temporarily inverts: The pan tool becomes the area selection tool, and the area selection tool becomes the pan tool.
When Ctrl is depressed, mousewheel zoom intervals are temporarily decreased.
Related articles: Common Concepts, Map Concept, Map Control Tutorial, Using Notifications and Events, Creating the Interface.

If it is true, interactivity is determined by and .

member.name: P:Telogis.GeoBase.MapCtrl.DoubleBuffering
member.summary: Double buffering allows Renderers to redraw without incurring the cost of a complete map redraw. Renderers on a double buffered map cannot interact with labels.

remarks.para: Double buffering only affects maps that have not changed zoom, size or center when a Renderer is added.

When double buffering is off (false), a Renderer added to a map may cause the labelling to be redrawn around the Renderer, allowing the Renderer to reserve space for itself and resulting in nicer looking maps where labels are not partially obscured by Renderers.

When double buffering is on (true), a Renderer added to a map is simply drawn over the previously rendered image of the map. This is faster but can result in clutter caused by partially obscured labels.
Also see .

member.name: P:Telogis.GeoBase.MapCtrl.Zooms
member.summary: Defines the set of zoom levels to use when the MapCtrl is operating in GeoStream mode.
member.remarks:
This property is ignored when the current repository is not a .
In GeoStream mode a zoom level represents the number of supertiles required to cover the world (horizontally). Zoom levels should always be ordered from lowest (far, or least zoomed) to highest (close). Only the specified zoom levels will be used when rendering the map.

member.name: P:Telogis.GeoBase.MapCtrl.TileSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the size of a tile.
member.remarks:
This property is ignored when the current repository is not a .
This value is the number of pixels wide and high each map tile should be.

member.name: P:Telogis.GeoBase.MapCtrl.TilePerSuperTile
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of tiles per supertile.

member.name: P:Telogis.GeoBase.MapCtrl.ZoomLevel
member.summary: Defines the current zoom level for a MapCtrl operating in GeoStream mode. This differs from Zoom, in that ZoomLevel is expressed in terms of the array of Zooms; ZoomLevel is an index into the array.

remarks.para: This property is ignored when the current repository is not a .

When in GeoStream mode this property corresponds to the index into the Zooms array that is currently set. In GeoStream mode this property is generally preferable to using Zoom as it sets the exact zoom level, while using Zoom will cause the map to zoom to the closest available ZoomLevel that is as big or larger than the requested Zoom.

member.name: P:Xheo.Licensing.RegistrationForm.SerialNumberMask
member.summary: Gets or sets the serial number mask used to provide a cleaner interface for the end user.
member.remarks: The serial number mask identifies character placeholders and character units (separated by dashes). The character pattern is then used to create a set of input boxes that mimic pattern. A sample pattern would be XXXXXXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXXXXXXXXXX for a GUID.

member.name: P:Xheo.Licensing.RegistrationForm.SerialNumberRegex
member.summary: Gets or sets a regular expression used to validate the format of the serial number. This is not used to secure the application, only to provide immediate feedback to the user if they have typed the number wrong.

member.name: P:Xheo.Licensing.RegistrationForm.GetLicense
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates if a license should be requested from the License server defined by .
member.remarks: When true the user can enter a serial number to register their product. When the user selects OK, a request will be made to the license server to get the license indicated by the serial number. There are no semantics placed on the value of the serial number and developers are free to develop their own numbering schemes.

member.name: P:Xheo.Licensing.RegistrationForm.GotLicense
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates if a license was downloaded during the registration process. contains the path where the license was saved.
member.remarks: Even when GetLicense is false, if the license server returns an XML license it will be saved.

member.name: P:Xheo.Licensing.RegistrationForm.SendToWebPage
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates if a license should be requested from the License server defined by .
member.remarks: When true the values of the form will be sent in a query string to the web page defined by . When false the information is sent directly to the license server.

member.name: T:Telogis.GeoBase.Navigation.SchematicTurnBox
member.summary: SchematicTurnBox draws a visual aid when navigating a turn or, more generally, a .
member.remarks: SchematicTurnBox uses predefined images for each possible type of navigation event, as well as a progress bar to indicate the approach to the point where the navigation event takes place.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Navigation.SchematicTurnBox.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a SchematicTurnBox that uses the default images. Images should be available in your TurnIcons folder.

member.name: M:Telogis.GeoBase.Navigation.SchematicTurnBox.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a SchematicTurnBox that uses images from a specified folder.
member.param: The path for the folder that contains the images for displaying different movements.

remarks.para: The images folder should contain the following images (in png, bmp, gif, or jpeg format):

item.description: Uturn by going around a traffic circle in left-hand traffic.
Uturn by going around a traffic circle in right-hand traffic.
Turn left at the traffic circle in left-hand traffic.
Turn left at the traffic circle in right-hand traffic.
Turn right at the traffic circle in left-hand traffic.
Turn right at the traffic circle in right-hand traffic.
Go straight through the traffic circle in left-hand traffic.
Go straight through the traffic circle in right-hand traffic.
Make a uturn in left-hand traffic (by turning right).
Make a uturn in right-hand traffic (by turning left).
